titlePart.text: SECTION G PHYSICS
INSTRUMENTS
COMPUTING
CALCULATING
COUNTING
titlePart.entryReference: combinations of writing appliances with computing devices

noteParagraph.text: Attention is drawn to the notes (particularly the definition of the term "variable") on page 7 of this Section.
The term "data" is understood to be synonymous with "information", and the term "information" is therefore not used in sub-class or .

The terms "calculating" and "computing" are both understood to include, inter alia, operations on numerical values and on data expressed in numerical form; of these words "computing" is used throughout the class. "Computation" is derived from this interpretation of "computing". In the French language the word "calcul" will serve for either word.
In those sub-classes which include simulators:
a simulator in class is concerned with the mathematics of computing the existing or anticipated conditions within the real device or system;
control functions derived from simulators are not in class but are generally in class , although they may be in the sub-class for the device controlled;
measurement of an individual variable to serve as an input to a simulator is in class ;

a simulator is regarded as a teaching or training device proper to class if the simulator gives perceptible sensations having a likeness to the sensations the student would experience in reality in response to actions taken by him. Simulators which demonstrate, by means involving computing, the functioning of apparatus or of a system are in class , if no provision exists elsewhere. Components of simulators, if identical with real devices or machines, are classified in the relevant sub-class for these devices or machines and not in class or ;
a simulator may use the same time scale as the real device or operate on an expanded or compressed time scale;
models of real devices to reduced or expanded scales are not regarded as simulators.

The term "record carrier" is understood to mean a body, such as a cylinder, disc, card, tape, or wire, capable of permanently holding information, which can be read-off by a sensing element movable relative to the recorded information.

titlePart.text: DIGITAL COMPUTERS IN WHICH AT LEAST PART OF THE COMPUTATION IS EFFECTED ELECTRICALLY
ARRANGEMENTS FOR HANDLING DIGITAL DATA
titlePart.entryReference: computers in which a part of the computation is effected hydraulically or pneumatically
self-contained input or output peripheral equipment

noteParagraph.text: In this sub-class, the expression "handling" includes processing or transporting of data.

titlePart.text: Details of data-processing equipment not covered by groups
Digital function generators
Generating or distributing clock signals or signals derived directly therefrom
Input arrangements for transferring data to be processed into a form capable of being handled by the computer
Output arrangements for transferring data from processing unit to output unit, e.g. interface arrangements
Manual input, e.g. key, dial
titlePart.entryReference: electronic switches characterised by the way in which the control signals are generated

titlePart.text: Arrangements for converting discrete items of information into a coded form, e.g. keyboards for generating alphanumeric codes, operand codes, instruction codes
for insertion of the decimal point
Arrangements for converting the position of a member into a coded form
titlePart.entryReference: position-indicating arrangements with manually operated feeler per se

titlePart.text: using a movable member co-operating with a display device, e.g. lightpen, joystick, tracing-ball
wherein the display device is a cathode-ray tube
Digital input from, or digital output to, one or more distant stations
Digital input using the sampling of an analogue quantity at regular intervals of time
Digital input from, or digital output to, record carriers
from or to individual record carriers, e.g. punched card
Digital output to typewriters
Digital output to print unit
Digital output to plotter
Digital output to display device
titlePart.entryReference: output arrangements for producing a permanent visual presentation of the output data

titlePart.text: using display panels
using cathode-ray tubes
Sound input
sound output
titlePart.entryReference: conversion of speech into digital information or vice versa

titlePart.text: Digital input from automatic curve follower
Methods or arrangements for data conversion without changing the order or content of the data handled
for converting multi-digit numbers from one notational system to another, e.g. decimal to four-line binary
for series/parallel conversion or vice versa and adapted for conjoint operation with a processing unit
for changing the speed of data flow, i.e. speed regularising
Methods or arrangements for processing data by operating upon the order or content of the data handled
Comparing digital values
Identity comparison, i.e. for like or unlike values
Arrangements for sorting, selecting, merging, or comparing data on individual record carriers
titlePart.entryReference: conveying record carriers from one station to another

titlePart.text: Sorting, i.e. grouping record carriers in numerical or other ordered sequence according to the classification of at least some of the information they carry
titlePart.entryReference: by merging two or more sets of carriers in ordered sequence

titlePart.text: Selecting, i.e. obtaining data of one kind from those record carriers which are identifiable by data of a second kind from a mass of ordered or randomly-distributed record carriers
with provision for printing-out a list of selected items
Merging, i.e. combining at least two sets of record carriers each arranged in the same ordered sequence to produce a single set having the same ordered sequence
Combined merging and sorting
Comparing separate sets of record carriers arranged in the same sequence to determine whether at least some of the data in one set is identical with that in the other set or sets
Arrangements for sorting, selecting, merging, or comparing data on continuous record carriers, e.g. tape, drum, disc

Sorting, i.e. extracting data from one or more carriers, re-arranging the data in numerical or other ordered sequence, and re-recording the sorted data on the original carrier or on a different carrier or set of carriers
the sorted data being recorded on the original record carrier within the same space in which the data had been recorded prior to their sorting, without using intermediate storage
Selecting, i.e. choosing digital data of a predetermined kind from a record carrier which has two or more kinds of digital data
titlePart.entryReference: special purpose computers for information retrieval, for compiling abstracts

titlePart.text: with provisions for printing-out a list of selected items
Merging, i.e. combining data contained in ordered sequence on at least two record carriers to produce a single carrier or set of carriers having all the original data in the ordered sequence
Comparing separate record carriers with data arranged in the same sequence to determine whether at least one of the data on one carrier is identical with that on the other
Combined merging and sorting
Methods or arrangements for performing computations using exclusively denominational number representation, e.g. using binary, ternary, decimal representation
using contact-making devices, e.g. electromagnetic relay
Adding
Subtracting
Multiplying
Dividing
using electromechanical counter-type accumulators
using non-contact-making devices, e.g. tube, solid state device
using unspecified devices
Computations with a radix, other than binary, 8, 16 or decimal, e.g. ternary, negative or imaginary radices, mixed radix
Adding
Subtracting
Multiplying
Dividing
using column-shifting
for evaluating functions by calculation
Trigonometric functions
Co-ordinate transformations
Powers or roots
Logarithmic or exponential functions
using electro-optical devices
Random or pseudo-random number generators
Methods or arrangements for performing computations using a digital non-denominational number representation, i.e. number representation without radix
Computing devices using combinations of denominational and non-denominational quantity representations
Performing operations exclusively by counting total number of pulses
Digital differential analysers, i.e. computing devices for differentiation, integration or solving differential or integral equations, using pulses representing increments
Other incremental computing devices for solving difference equations
titlePart.entryReference: differential analysers using hybrid computing techniques

titlePart.text: wherein pulses represent unitary increments only
using pulse rate multipliers or dividers
using stochastic pulse trains, i.e. randomly occurring pulses the average pulse rates of which represent numbers
using residue arithmetic
Arrangements for programme control, e.g. control unit
using wired connections, e.g. plugboard
using record carriers containing only programme instructions
using stored programme, i.e. using internal store of processing equipment to receive and retain programme
Micro-control or micro-programme arrangements
Loading of the micro-programme
Address formation of the next micro-instruction
Enhancement of operational speed, e.g. by using several micro-control devices operating in parallel
Arrangements for executing machine-instructions
Address formation of the next instruction, e.g. incrementing the instruction counter, jump
Accessing the instruction operand, e.g. indirect addressing, variable length operand
with provisions for address modifications, e.g. indexing
Concurrent instruction execution, e.g. pipeline, lock ahead
Arrangements for executing subprogrammes, i.e. combinations of several instructions
Formation of subprogramme-jump address or of return address
Arrangements for executing specific programmes, e.g. emulator, compiler, for Polish notation
Multiprogramming arrangements, e.g. using interrupt
Priority circuits therefor
Error detection
Error correction
Monitoring
titlePart.entryReference: methods or arrangements for verifying the correctness of marking on a record carrier
in coding or decoding, in general

titlePart.text: Error detection or correction by redundancy in data representation, e.g. by using checking codes
Adding special bits or symbols to the coded information, e.g. parity check, casting out nines or elevens
using codes with inherent redundancy, e.g. m-out-of-n codes
Error detecting or correction of the data by redundancy in operation
Error detection or correction of the data by redundancy in hardware
using passive faultmasking of the redundant circuits, e.g. by quadding or by majority decision circuits
using active faultmasking, e.g. by switching out faulty elements or by switching in spare elements
Detection or location of defective hardware by testing during standby operation or during idle time
Marginal checking
by performing a computation, the result of which is known
by checking the correct order or processing
Monitoring
with visual indication of the functioning of the machine
Recording or statistical evaluation of computer activity, e.g. of down time, of input/output operation
Interconnection of storage devices with the functional units of the data-processing equipment
the storage device being of the transit-time type, e.g. delay line
the storage device requiring relative movement with respect to the recording or sensing element
the storage device being a random-access store
being a magnetic store
Data-processing equipment characterised by the combination of functions covered by group and at least one other main group

noteParagraph.text: Inventions classified in the sub-groups of are classified both in groups and also in groups so far as each of these sets of groups is relevant to the invention.

titlePart.text: manually operated with input through keyboard and computation using a built-in programme, e.g. desk calculator
programmed simultaneously with the introduction of data to be processed, e.g. on the same record carrier
with a store which receives a complete set of programme steps before the individual data to be processed are introduced
using a plugboard for programming

having provision for both printed and punched output
Calculating-punches
Combinations of two or more digital computers each having at least an arithmetic unit, a programme unit and a register, e.g. for a simultaneous processing of several programmes
in which a programme is changed according to experience gained by the computer itself during a complete run
Learning machines
characterized by a specific application so far as the design or construction of the computing part is concerned

Function evaluation by approximation methods, e.g. inter- or extrapolation, smoothing, least mean square method
for evaluating statistical data
for language translation
for information retrieval
for compiling abstracts
titlePart.entryReference: selecting data from a dynamic store

titlePart.text: for medical purposes
